I actually lost to a 4 AD marksman team the other night as Taric with 450 armor. You'd be surprised how quickly you become worthless as a tank when you can't focus more than two of the 4 targets you need to. They pretty much negated my entire armor pool with LW and BC. Do not nerf Tabi.

And you know what's funny? I say this all the time to various people on various outlets, and they never understood it. At least someone else does. Maybe you'll understand, too, why I hate the Galio relaunch.

To be honest I REALLY love Galio's new kit.
It looks super fun to play, use and see.

But his  design is SUPER Boring, Bland and Lazy.

The original Galio was the stereotypical dumb gargoyle cliche flipped on it's head, so he was somber, intelligent and wise.

Instead he's now another big dumb arrogant brute with an obsession with punching.
The old Galio was so nice to see and hear, the new one is just Malphite and Garen's baby.  

I LOVE The Gameplay team on VGU's, but the design teams always suck at their job.

I'm not really talking about the entirely new Champion they're releasing and just naming him Galio so they can delete the old one. I'm talking more along the lines of a removal of an insurance policy. Rammus was supposed to be your insurance policy against full-AD teams and Riot nerfed him when it was finally his time to shine and remind all those AD why building a team full of them was a bad idea. Galio is supposed to be that check to AP, but now that check is gone. Granted, AP never really got to the point where building a team full of them was a good idea since the majority are built around burst vs sustained, but the fact remained that Galio was our mage counter. Not anymore, though.

Every champion has become more and more self sufficient and less team-reliant to function and I also think this is a bad direction. But that's a topic for another time.

At this point League of Legends is no longer a traditional MOBA, for better or for worse. 
So including things such as pure counters to other team comps (Like in DOTA) is not something that's really going to happen anymore.

It's more the end result of very early design decisions in League's infancy to allow "everyone" a chance to carry. Everyone scaled with items and was expected a base level of income to allow impactful purchases. Dota doesn't have that kind of assurance and makes sure there are heroes who function on a shoestring budget without becoming too much of a nuisance if afforded more opportunity for gold (at least, before the Level Tree was introduced). In short, they didn't want players to feel like they had no impact on the game, even though a "ward bot" usually contributes more to victory than anyone else, as vision really is that powerful in this genre.

When you design everyone to scale, this is where you eventually end up. Champions start relying on their team less, are more able to generate gold for themselves, and afforded more opportunities to carry the game. It was pretty clear, even in the beginning, that the original Riot developers didn't like the "pick support, buy wards all game" role and wanted everyone to play something that could build other items and "have fun." That view has been taken to the extreme in recent years, though, and it's showing with all these reworks/re-releases/new champions.

Those things all got there through a series of RIOT nerfing one aspect, then making part of it into a different effect all together to compensate for lowering the initial aspect in the first place.

Originally it slowed and silenced, then they determined the silence was OP as it shut everyone down so they made it a blind and slow, with the hopes of shutting down late game carries for a few seconds so that your team could CC chain and focus them down before they melted your team.  Well, the blind countered their beloved ADCs too much, so then we get patch 1.0.0.108 
> Now reduces (auto/basic) attack damage by 70% and ability/item damage by 35% instead of blinding for the duration.


Okay, so now Exhaust slows, reduces ability damage by 35%, reduces item damage by 35% and reduces basic attack damage by 70%.  It was nerfed in its primary goal, and still allows those farmed late game carries to pump out 30% of their DPS during this duration; to compensate this, all ability damages are lowered by 35% making exhaust more target agnostic.

Fast forward 44 patches (or 23 months) to 1.0.0.152 and Exhaust gets changed around again.  

> Movement speed reduction reduced to 30% from 40%.
> New Effect: Now reduces attack speed by 50%.
> New Effect: Now reduces all damage dealt by 30% from 70% for attacks and 30% from abilities/items 

Here what they tried to do was improve clarity by not having different % damage reduction values, and nerf its effect as seen by the 35% -> 30% reduction, and reducing the slow; which was important as only the highest slow applies at any time, and the meta then was influenced by items having 30%, or 35% slows so making exhaust into a 30% slow meant it was never more powerful than those other slows including ones by Randuin's, Frozen Mallet (this was in fratmogs season) and Rylai's and so basically ceases to exist as soon as one of those slows is applied

They still wanted it to be an anti-late-game-carry spell, so they replaced the additionally damage reduction with an attack speed slow.  Now, originally the attack speed slow was actually stronger than the damage reduction that was removed, making the net change on an ADC 10% more movement speed for 10% less auto attack DPS during Exhaust, and making non-auto reliant champions better off with lower damage reduction and a lesser slow.

Three years ago they inverted the numbers, and bumped up the cast range.
  
>     Attack speed cripple reduced to 30% from 50%.
>     Damage reduction increased to 50% from 30%.
>     Range increased to 650 from 550.  

Eight patches later, in 4.13 we get this.

>     Damage reduction reduced to 40% from 50%.
>     New Effect: Now reduces the target's armor and magic resistance by 10. 

Where RIOT realized 50% damage reduction was a bit too high, and it was starting to be a tankier meta, so they slapped a resist shred on to compensate for the nerf.

Exhaust was originally an offensive spell that became so good at preventing retaliations and escapes that it was redesigned to counter late game ADCs.  Since then it has only been spread out to more and more targets until it has the wide variety it has today.  

Exhaust went untouched since July 30th, 2014 and has been completely balanced this entire fucking time.  The recent changes were not necessary, and you are mischategorizing the purpose of this summoner spell.

  
Also, they've nerfed ghost multiple times for competing with flash, and change exhaust when it gets picked more than ignite with seemingly random changes that they even go the opposite direction of in the next round of nerfs/buffs.  All told, I'm inclined to agree with KrakenKnight.

Not really, flash and ghost serve a purpose, but if a spell gets chosen for the purpose that the other is supposed to fill, it will get nerfed. Why even take ignite when you can take exhuast and have the same effect + SOME MORE STUFF which one sounds better? Ofc its exhuast why not do some more dmg to someone, but they do a lot less dmg to you in return. it's obviously going to be the exhuast.

Ignite actually does damage, it is true damage, it reveals and marks the target and applies grievous wounds.  Out of all of that, the only similarity shared with exhaust is marking the target, albeit in a rather different manner.

Exhaust worked as a slight damage amp, if you really wanted to try to convert the amp into EHP negated then it would be 1/10 * (target max hp) less pEHP and mEHP, but that still is in no way actual damage.

In comparison, both ghost and flash provide utility through movement and nothing more.
Youre looking at it as just raw dmg, but it is more about utility, exhuast vastly outscales ignite. Exhuast provides much much more than ignite still even after the nerf.

So much disinfo and exaggeration on Nina Tabi in this video holy hell. 

1. Tabi does not reduce On-Hit damage so MF's Love Tap passive damage does not get reduced. That includes BOTRK's passive, Fiora's Vital Points, and Irelia's W that you were 99% sure about. You saying it blocks abilities is not only misleading but a complete strawman. It only blocks Basic Attacks and Basic Attack Modifiers.

2. "you're spending 800 gold to take away 6k of theirs" is an absolute over exaggeration. While yes you're blocking 30-40 lethality but you're sure aint blocking all that damage and dusk blade proc. So in reality, Ninja only takes away 600-800 gold from them. So its pretty even. In other words, it does its job.

3. Tabi's Passive does not gain more value as you gain more armor. INSTEAD it loses more value the more armor you receive. Lets say you have 100 armor which equals 50% physical dmg reduction. Ninja Tabi's passive is 12%. Based on how Riot does calculations, both combined will only block 56% damage. That is literally half of Tabi's Value. Like Doran's Shield's block, it loses more value the more you gain resistances. 

4. Google lolwiki next time.

Reductions are multiplicatively more powerful the more they are stacked on a 100-0 scale. 

For example, if you have 90% reduction, adding 1% to that may seem like a little, but you're still reducing the damage you would have taken by 10%. 

12% is 12%. No matter what. Damage reduction does not get less effective the more of it is stacked. The problem is % penetration in the game, not the efficiency of stacking armor/damage reductions. 

For example: Stacking MR still completely fucks APs, even with Void Staff. There's a reason that isn't an issue with armor.
